awd_titl_txt: NeTS: Small: The MOLES: Enabling Wireless Sensor Networks in Underground
awd_abstract_narration:
Wireless Underground Sensor Networks (WUSNs), i.e., networks of wireless sensor nodes that operate below the ground surface, are the enabling technology of many emerging applications, such as intelligent agriculture, underground pipelines and power grid monitoring, oil reservoir monitoring, concealed border patrol, earthquake and landslide forecasting, and underground mine disaster prevention and rescue, amongst others. Despite their potential advantages, the realization of WUSNs is very challenging. The peculiarities of the underground environments prevent the direct use of most, if not all, existing wireless communication and networking solutions, mainly due to the very high path loss, small communication range, and high dynamics of electromagnetic (EM) waves in the underground environment. The objective of this project is to address the unique challenges for the realization of WUSNs in challenging underground environments. The proposed research is built on top of novel Magnetic Induction (MI)-based communication mechanisms as well as system architectures in underground soil medium, oil reservoirs, and mines and tunnels. This particular project has contributions along four major thrusts. First, a cross-layer communication framework based on the MI channel characteristics is proposed to achieve high-throughput, energy-efficient, and reliable underground communications. Second, a new Received Magnetic Filed Strength (RMFS)-based localization paradigm is proposed to exploit the unique multi-path and fading-free propagation properties of MI-based signals, which guarantees the accuracy, simplicity, and convenience of the localization strategy. Third, an optimal MI-based network deployment strategy is proposed for different WUSNs applications with the objective to minimize the coil density while maintaining the required bandwidth constraint and reliability requirements. Finally, a physical MI-based WUSN testbed is developed, which consists of our own designed MI-based sensor devices and an engineered underground environment, to validate our proposed solutions. 

The proposed research is expected to pave the way for the realization and implementation of emerging WUSNs applications, which bring significant advances in the industrial productivity and homeland security, e.g., concealed border patrol. This project will bring together researchers in the areas of information theory, radio design, and networking, and enable the establishment of new research connections and interpretations. The project will support two graduate students. The solutions of the project will also result in patents for the proposed techniques and novel system architectures. The research results will be disseminated in important scientific conferences, journals and premier magazines of the field. The developed simulation tool and physical testbed will serve as the evaluation platform for the research community.

por.por_cntn:
Wireless Underground Sensor Networks (WUSNs) are networks of wireless sensor nodes operating below the ground surface, which are envisioned to provide real-time monitoring capabilities in challenging underground environments including soil medium, oil and water reservoirs, underground mines and tunnels. The realization of WUSNs will lead to many emerging applications, such as intelligent and efficient agriculture, underground pipelines and power grid monitoring, oil reservoir monitoring, concealed border patrol, earthquake and landslide forecasting, underground mine disaster prevention and rescue, amongst others. The focus of the MOLES project is to enable reliable and efficient wireless communications in WUSNs. The new results greatly increase our knowledge of both theoretical and practical aspects in WUSNs. The outcomes of the MOLES project enable us to realize very reliable and efficient wireless communications in WUSNs. Particularly, the following items can be listed as the key outcomes of this project:

 1. Developed a novel cross-layer communication framework for MI-based networks in dynamically changing underground environments. The proposed framework combines a joint selection of modulation, channel coding and power control, a transmitter-based CDMA scheme and a geographic forwarding paradigm. This framework is aimed to efficiently exploit the MI channel to guarantee a high network throughput, to minimize the energy consumption, and to guarantee application-level QoS. The proposed cross-layered communication solution takes the impact of the damaged or lost MI coils into account. The main concepts are:

  • Evaluation for the critical environment information of underground oil reservoirs that affects the transmission qualities of MI-based communications.
  • Three layer protocol stack for WUSNs in underground oil reservoirs.
  • Cross-layer framework to optimize the communication functionalities of different layers.
  • Distributed Environment-Aware Protocol (DEAP) design to solve the proposed cross-layer framework.
2. Developed a new Received Magnetic Field Strength (RMFS)-based localization framework which exploits the unique properties of the MI field to determine the locations of the randomly deployed sensor nodes in oil reservoirs and track the moving targets (e.g., miners and vehicles in underground mines and tunnels). The novelty of the proposed framework relies on the unique multi-path and fading free propagation properties of MI-based signals which guarantee the accuracy, simplicity, and convenience of the localization strategy. Towards this, the relationship between the received MI field strength and the transmitted distance is analyzed based on the characteristics of the RMFS. Based on such MI-based distance estimation strategy, the localization problem can be solved by jointly applying weighted maximum likelihood estimation (WMLE), semi-definite programming (SDP) relaxation, alternating direction augmented Lagrangian method (ADM), and conjugate gradient algorithm (CGA). The main concepts are:
  • RMFS measurements for designing localization in underground oil reservoirs.
  • Localization framework for WSNs in underground oil reservoirs.
  • Fast initial positioning from ADM.
  • Fine-grained positioning from CGA.
3. Developed an optimal MI-based WUSN deployment framework for different structures in underground environments. The optimal deployment locations are determined with an objective to minimize the coil density while maintaining the required bandwidth constraints and reliability requirements. The main concepts are:
  • The effects of coil layout and geometries such as the number of turns, turn width, and turn spacing on the inductance of planar spiral coils.
  • Estimate the maximum antenna inductance for the targeted footprint and determine that an impedance matching network is needed.
  • Design and simulate an impedance matching network based on the impedance characteristics of the antenna and transceiver.
  • Optimize the antenna design by studying the effects of turn number and horizontal offset on coil coupling and mutual inductance.

4. Developed a physical MI-based WUSN testbed to validate the performance of the proposed solutions. The MI-based sensor nodes are designed, developed and fabricated along with the MI-coils as antenna and transceivers design. Passive and Active Sensor Node are designed based on SOC (System on Chip) applied to RFID. The main concepts are:

 

  • Low energy requirements (implementation in hostile environments).
  • MI communication (NFC and RFID with passive/active sensors).
  • Harvesting energy capability (The harvesting energy process is performed via the energy management unit that harvests the surplus of the power used for NFC communication)
  • Hardware miniaturization (Hardware compatible electronic ICs available in very small package)

In addition, engineered oil reservoir environment is designed so that the performance and feasibility of physical MI-based WUSNs can be tested in the extremely harsh underground conditions.

For the broader impact of the project, the research results will be incorporated to the wireless communications and networks related courses within the School of Electrical and Computer Engineering, at the Georgia Institute of Technology, both at undergraduate and graduate levels. 3 PhD students 1 Post-doctoral fellow were trained to become experts in this fast evolving field. Besides, 1 Master student designed and simulated different type of sensor antennas. The collective research effort of the team will also be used in class projects as an educational tool to provide deep understanding of WUSNs. The research results are disseminated in first-rate scientific conferences, journals and premier magazines.
